function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Visiting parks on weekends and weekdays without a preference may lead to crowded spaces, increasing the risk of disease transmission.","Impact":"Higher likelihood of disease spread due to crowded public spaces.","Mitigation":"Enforcing capacity limits, promoting alternate outdoor spaces, and scheduling park visits to reduce crowding.","Technologies":"Location-based capacity tracking systems, crowd density monitoring sensors, and mobile apps for park reservations.","People":"Park visitors, surrounding communities, and city residents.","Owner":"Park management, local authorities, and urban planning organizations."},{"Description":"Majority of respondents visited parks alone during the confinement, contradicting the recommended social gathering guidelines.","Impact":"Increased risk of isolation and decreased social interaction, leading to mental health issues.","Mitigation":"Promoting safe group activities, creating social distancing circles, and organizing outdoor events with safety measures.","Technologies":"Social distancing apps, event management platforms, and communication tools for public health directives.","People":"Solo park visitors, individuals experiencing social isolation, and public health officials.","Owner":"Community organizations, mental health support services, and local government."},{"Description":"Visitors' tendency to wander through the space rather than staying in one place during the confinement may result in increased interactions and overlapping of individuals, elevating disease transmission risk.","Impact":"Higher potential for disease spread due to close contact and prolonged exposure in public spaces.","Mitigation":"Designating walking paths, creating one-way circulation routes, and providing signage for physical distancing guidance.","Technologies":"Digital mapping tools, wayfinding systems, and contact tracing apps.","People":"Park visitors, nearby residents, and essential workers.","Owner":"Urban planners, park management, and public health authorities."}]}
